elements.content: By regulating secondary building units and inducing multiplicate metal–ligand interactions, an unstable anionic framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust neutral framework MOF-Mn4 . Although possessing same network topology, MOF-Mn4 shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over MOF-Mn4Cl.
elements.clean_text: By regulating secondary building units and inducing multiplicate metal-ligand interactions, an unstable anionic framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust neutral framework MOF-Mn4 . Although possessing same network topology, MOF-Mn4  shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over MOF-Mn4Cl.

elements.content: On the basis of the idea of regulating the coordination environment of secondary building units in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) via inducing multiplicate metal−ligand interactions, an unstable framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust framework MOF-Mn4 . Although both MOFs possess similar the -type topologies and pore features, the neutral stable MOF-Mn4 shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over the unstable anionic MOF-Mn4Cl.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the idea of regulating the coordination environment of secondary building units in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) via inducing multiplicate metal-ligand interactions, an unstable framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust framework MOF-Mn4 . Although both MOFs possess similar  the -type topologies and pore features, the neutral stable MOF-Mn4  shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over the unstable anionic MOF-Mn4Cl.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystal Engineering of Nanoporous Materials for Gas Storage and Separation

Design and fabrication of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increasing interest due to their aesthetic structural topologies and potential applications in gas adsorption and storage, catalyst supports, electrode materials, chemical sensing, controlled release of drugs, and light harvesting. However, almost all of the applications, especially gas sorption performance, are highly dependent on the permanent porosity of MOFs. Except for conventional solvent-exchange and heat-treatment, some special activated methods, such as supercritical carbon dioxide exchange and freeze-drying, have been used to maintain the structural integrity of MOFs. Compared to the above physically activated method, chemical processes (including postsynthetic metathesis and oxidation (PSMO), self-interpenetration, inserting rigid pillar ligand, etc.) can more fundamentally optimize the stability of the MOFs, owing to the change of metal-donor affinity and linkage. For example, Zhang’s groups provided a strategy of inserting a rigid pillar ligand to structurally modify an unstable lvt -type framework into a rigid seh -type framework. Utilizing a PSMO strategy, Zhou and co-workers obtained robust PCN-426-Fe­(III) and PCN-426-Cr­(III) from unstable PCN-426-Mg via stepwise single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. However, these transformations are usually accompanied by the change of metal nodes and/or topologies of the frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystal Engineering of Nanoporous Materials for Gas Storage and Separation

Design and fabrication of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increasing interest due to their aesthetic structural topologies and potential applications in gas adsorption and storage, catalyst supports, electrode materials, chemical sensing, controlled release of drugs, and light harvesting. However, almost all of the applications, especially gas sorption performance, are highly dependent on the permanent porosity of MOFs. Except for conventional solvent-exchange and heat-treatment, some special activated methods, such as supercritical carbon dioxide exchange and freeze-drying, have been used to maintain the structural integrity of MOFs. Compared to the above physically activated method, chemical processes (including postsynthetic metathesis and oxidation (PSMO), self-interpenetration, inserting rigid pillar ligand, etc.) can more fundamentally optimize the stability of the MOFs, owing to the change of metal-donor affinity and linkage. For example, Zhang's groups provided a strategy of inserting a rigid pillar ligand to structurally modify an unstable  lvt -type framework into a rigid  seh -type framework. Utilizing a PSMO strategy, Zhou and co-workers obtained robust PCN-426-Fe(III) and PCN-426-Cr(III) from unstable PCN-426-Mg via stepwise single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. However, these transformations are usually accompanied by the change of metal nodes and/or topologies of the frameworks.

elements.content: Here, we provide a new idea for enhancing MOFs’ stability via regulating coordination environment of secondary building units (SBUs), including extracting central atoms and changing coordinated mode of ligands. These adjustments will promote formation of some additional interactions between donors and metals, while metal nodes and topologies of the original frameworks are still kept, which is very important for some special applications for MOFs, such as fluorescence, biological monitoring, as well as gas sorption/separation. The pores with a slightly different environment in MOFs are a better platform to study in detail the effect of environment on gas sorption properties. However, few studies have been reported on this topic.
elements.clean_text: Here, we provide a new idea for enhancing MOFs' stability via regulating coordination environment of secondary building units (SBUs), including extracting central atoms and changing coordinated mode of ligands. These adjustments will promote formation of some additional interactions between donors and metals, while metal nodes and topologies of the original frameworks are still kept, which is very important for some special applications for MOFs, such as fluorescence, biological monitoring, as well as gas sorption/separation. The pores with a slightly different environment in MOFs are a better platform to study in detail the effect of environment on gas sorption properties. However, few studies have been reported on this topic.

elements.content: In this work, we report the synthesis, structural characterizations, and sorption properties of two new MOFs based on a triangle BTTC3– ligands (H3BTTC = benzo-(1,2;3,4;5,6)-tris­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid) ligand, namely, [H2NMe2]3n ­·[(Mn4Cl)3­(BTTC)8­(H2O)12]2n (MOF-Mn 4 Cl) and [(Mn4)3(BTTC)8­(H2O)12] n ­·[Mn­(OH)2­(H2O)4] n (MOF-Mn 4 ), which consist of chloride-centered square-planar [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− and [Mn4(COO)8] units linked by BTTC ligands, respectively. Although the two MOFs have similar the -type networks formed by the close packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages, the framework of MOF-Mn 4 Cl tends to collapse after the removal of solvent molecules and shows very low gas uptakes. However, once regulating the coordination environment of SBUs in this similar framework, the resulting MOF-Mn 4 is very robust and exhibits a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over the unstable anionic MOF-Mn 4 Cl.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we report the synthesis, structural characterizations, and sorption properties of two new MOFs based on a triangle BTTC3- ligands (H3BTTC = benzo-(1,2;3,4;5,6)-tris(thiophene-2'-carboxylic acid) ligand, namely, [H2NMe2]3n ⋅[(Mn4Cl)3(BTTC)8(H2O)12]2n  (MOF-Mn  4  Cl) and [(Mn4)3(BTTC)8(H2O)12] n ⋅[Mn(OH)2(H2O)4] n  (MOF-Mn  4 ), which consist of chloride-centered square-planar [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- and [Mn4(COO)8] units linked by BTTC ligands, respectively. Although the two MOFs have similar  the -type networks formed by the close packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages, the framework of MOF-Mn  4  Cl tends to collapse after the removal of solvent molecules and shows very low gas uptakes. However, once regulating the coordination environment of SBUs in this similar framework, the resulting MOF-Mn  4  is very robust and exhibits a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over the unstable anionic MOF-Mn  4  Cl.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of H3BTTC with MnCl2·2H2O in a mixture of DMA, MeOH, and aqueous HNO3 (65%) (DMA = N,N′-dimethylacetamide, MeOH = methanol) afforded the cubic crystals of MOF-Mn 4 Cl. Single crystal diffraction analysis reveals that MOF-Mn 4 Cl crystallizes in the cubic space group Pm3̅m and consists of chloride-centered square-planar [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− SBUs and triangle BTTC3– ligands with syn–syn carboxylic coordination mode (a). As shown in b, each Mn­(II) adopts a six coordinated octahedral geometry completed by four O atoms from different carboxyl groups of BTTC3– ligand, one μ4-Cl center, and one terminal H2O molecule.
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal reaction of H3BTTC with MnCl2⋅2H2O in a mixture of DMA, MeOH, and aqueous HNO3 (65%) (DMA = N,N'-dimethylacetamide, MeOH = methanol) afforded the cubic crystals of MOF-Mn  4  Cl. Single crystal diffraction analysis reveals that MOF-Mn  4  Cl crystallizes in the cubic space group Pm3̅m and consists of chloride-centered square-planar [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- SBUs and triangle BTTC3- ligands with syn-syn carboxylic coordination mode (a). As shown in b, each Mn(II) adopts a six coordinated octahedral geometry completed by four O atoms from different carboxyl groups of BTTC3- ligand, one μ4-Cl center, and one terminal H2O molecule.

elements.content: Crystal structures of MOF-Mn 4 Cl and MOF-Mn 4 . (a) The coordination environment of [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− SBU and BTTC ligand in MOF-Mn 4 Cl (gray: C; red: O; yellow: S; violet: Mn; lime: Cl). (b) The truncated octahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 Cl. (c) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 Cl. (d) The cubic packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages via sharing all of the triangular facets in both MOFs. (e) The diagram of the 3D framework of MOF-Mn 4 Cl. (f) The coordination environment of [Mn4(COO)8]− SBU and BTTC ligand in MOF-Mn 4 . (g) The truncated octahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 , in which [Mn­(OH)2­(H2O)4] unit is wrapped. (h) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 . (i) 3,8-Connected the topology derived from the structure of both MOFs. (j) The diagram of the 3D framework of MOF-Mn 4 .
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of MOF-Mn  4  Cl and MOF-Mn  4 . (a) The coordination environment of [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- SBU and BTTC ligand in MOF-Mn  4  Cl (gray: C; red: O; yellow: S; violet: Mn; lime: Cl). (b) The truncated octahedral cage in MOF-Mn  4  Cl. (c) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn  4  Cl. (d) The cubic packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages via sharing all of the triangular facets in both MOFs. (e) The diagram of the 3D framework of MOF-Mn  4  Cl. (f) The coordination environment of [Mn4(COO)8]- SBU and BTTC ligand in MOF-Mn  4 . (g) The truncated octahedral cage in MOF-Mn  4 , in which [Mn(OH)2(H2O)4] unit is wrapped. (h) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn  4 . (i) 3,8-Connected  the  topology derived from the structure of both MOFs. (j) The diagram of the 3D framework of MOF-Mn  4 .

elements.content: And then each Mn­(II) shares one μ4-Cl and two carboxylates with adjacent Mn­(II), forming a chloride-centered square-planar [Mn4(μ4-Cl) (COO)8]− SBU with D 4h symmetry. It is worth noting that the bond length (2.826 Å) of the Mn–Cl bond is longer than that (2.625 Å) of the previous reported [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− unit and other similar inorganic M4Cl units. In the structure, each [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− SBU is surrounded by eight BTTC3– ligands, while each BTTC3– ligand links three [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− SBUs. Moreover, there are two kinds of open cages in the whole framework. One is a octahedral cage with a diameter of about 2.1 nm (Mn···Mn distance), which is formed by six [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− squares as vertexes and eight BTTC3– ligands (b). All of the triangular facets on the octahedral cage are covered by BTTC3– ligands. Another is a cuboctahedral cage with a diameter of about 2.6 nm (Mn···Mn distance), which is constituted by 12 [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− squares as vertexes and eight BTTC3– ligands (c). In the cuboctahedral cages, eight triangular facets are shared with the octahedral cage and also covered by BTTC3– ligands, while six square facets are all opening. The close packing of these octahedral and cuboctahedral cages via sharing all of the triangular facets further extends the structure into a 3D open framework (d,e). Within these large octahedral and cuboctahedral cages, the framework possesses considerable void space, and the solvent accessible volume is estimated by PLATON to be about 67% of the total crystal volume. The cuboctahedral cages are interconnected, thereby forming 3D open channels with an aperture diameter of 2 nm; these channels are filled with disorder solvent molecules and balanced cations. From the topological point of view, the [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− squares and BTTC3– ligands can be regarded as 8- and 3-connecting nodes, respectively. Hence, the final framework is simplified into a (3,8)-connected the network (i), which has been known in several reported MOFs based on the similar inorganic M4Cl (or M4O) units connected by 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoic acid, triphenylene-2,6,10-tricarboxylate, 5,5′,10,10′,15,15′-hexameth-yltruxene-2,7,12-tricarboxyllate, or 1,3,5-tris­(tetrazol-5-yl)­benzene ligands. These MOFs were all stable for gas sorption upon activation or ion-exchange.
elements.clean_text: And then each Mn(II) shares one μ4-Cl and two carboxylates with adjacent Mn(II), forming a chloride-centered square-planar [Mn4(μ4-Cl) (COO)8]- SBU with D 4h  symmetry. It is worth noting that the bond length (2.826 Å) of the Mn-Cl bond is longer than that (2.625 Å) of the previous reported [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- unit and other similar inorganic M4Cl units. In the structure, each [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- SBU is surrounded by eight BTTC3- ligands, while each BTTC3- ligand links three [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- SBUs. Moreover, there are two kinds of open cages in the whole framework. One is a octahedral cage with a diameter of about 2.1 nm (Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance), which is formed by six [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- squares as vertexes and eight BTTC3- ligands (b). All of the triangular facets on the octahedral cage are covered by BTTC3- ligands. Another is a cuboctahedral cage with a diameter of about 2.6 nm (Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance), which is constituted by 12 [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- squares as vertexes and eight BTTC3- ligands (c). In the cuboctahedral cages, eight triangular facets are shared with the octahedral cage and also covered by BTTC3- ligands, while six square facets are all opening. The close packing of these octahedral and cuboctahedral cages via sharing all of the triangular facets further extends the structure into a 3D open framework (d,e). Within these large octahedral and cuboctahedral cages, the framework possesses considerable void space, and the solvent accessible volume is estimated by PLATON to be about 67% of the total crystal volume. The cuboctahedral cages are interconnected, thereby forming 3D open channels with an aperture diameter of 2 nm; these channels are filled with disorder solvent molecules and balanced cations. From the topological point of view, the [Mn4(μ4-Cl)(COO)8]- squares and BTTC3- ligands can be regarded as 8- and 3-connecting nodes, respectively. Hence, the final framework is simplified into a (3,8)-connected  the  network (i), which has been known in several reported MOFs based on the similar inorganic M4Cl (or M4O) units connected by 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 4,4',4"-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoic acid, triphenylene-2,6,10-tricarboxylate, 5,5',10,10',15,15'-hexameth-yltruxene-2,7,12-tricarboxyllate, or 1,3,5-tris(tetrazol-5-yl)benzene ligands. These MOFs were all stable for gas sorption upon activation or ion-exchange.

elements.content: Cubic crystals of MOF-Mn 4 can be successfully obtained by the reaction condition of MOF-Mn 4 Cl except that aqueous HNO3 was replaced by acetic acid. Single crystal diffraction analysis reveals that MOF-Mn 4 crystallizes in the cubic space group Fm3̅c, which is expectedly constructed by square-planar tetranuclear manganese units linked by triangle BTTC3– ligands. Notably, the syn–anti carboxylic coordination mode of each BTTC3– ligand is different from that in MOF-Mn 4 Cl (f). In the structure of MOF-Mn 4 , each Mn­(II) adopts a five coordinated square-pyramidal geometry, which is coordinated by four O atoms from four different BTTC3– ligands and one O atom from terminal water molecular. Each Mn­(II) is bridged to each of two other neighboring Mn­(II) through two carboxyl group via syn–trans configuration, forming a square [Mn4(COO)8] SBU. Additionally, a weak coordination interaction between O3 and Mn1 (Mn···O = 2.637 Å) can be observed (f). Consequently, the symmetry of the [Mn4(COO)8] SBU reduces to C 4h owing to the change of coordination mode of BTTC3– ligands. Although some structural details are different from MOF-Mn 4 Cl, MOF-Mn 4 also has octahedral and cuboctahedral cages consisting of the linkage of [Mn4(COO)8] SBUs and BTTC3– ligands (g,h). The close packing of these octahedral and cuboctahedral cages is also similar to that of MOF-Mn 4 Cl, resulting in the 3D framework of MOF-Mn 4 with the topology (d,i,j). Interestingly, there is an isolated [Mn­(OH)2(H2O)4] unit inside each twisted octahedral cage (g). The solvent accessible volume of MOF-Mn 4 is about 62.5% of the total crystal volume, which is slight lower than that of MOF-Mn 4 Cl. Thus, it can be considered as successful tuning of the coordination environment of SBUs in MOF-Mn 4 Cl. Meanwhile, the original anionic framework turns into a neutral one. In the previous work, Zhou’s group presented a neutral meso-MOF-2, which was constructed by connecting square-planar tetranuclear Cd­(II) SBUs with BTTC3– ligands, and retained permanent porosity upon heating activation. MOF-Mn 4 is isostructural with meso-MOF-2 because of the presence of a square-planar tetranuclear Mn­(II) unit which has not been reported so far. It encourages us to explore the gas sorption property of MOF-Mn 4 .
elements.clean_text: Cubic crystals of MOF-Mn  4  can be successfully obtained by the reaction condition of MOF-Mn  4  Cl except that aqueous HNO3 was replaced by acetic acid. Single crystal diffraction analysis reveals that MOF-Mn  4  crystallizes in the cubic space group Fm3̅c, which is expectedly constructed by square-planar tetranuclear manganese units linked by triangle BTTC3- ligands. Notably, the syn-anti carboxylic coordination mode of each BTTC3- ligand is different from that in MOF-Mn  4  Cl (f). In the structure of MOF-Mn  4 , each Mn(II) adopts a five coordinated square-pyramidal geometry, which is coordinated by four O atoms from four different BTTC3- ligands and one O atom from terminal water molecular. Each Mn(II) is bridged to each of two other neighboring Mn(II) through two carboxyl group via syn-trans configuration, forming a square [Mn4(COO)8] SBU. Additionally, a weak coordination interaction between O3 and Mn1 (Mn⋅⋅⋅O = 2.637 Å) can be observed (f). Consequently, the symmetry of the [Mn4(COO)8] SBU reduces to C 4h  owing to the change of coordination mode of BTTC3- ligands. Although some structural details are different from MOF-Mn  4  Cl, MOF-Mn  4  also has octahedral and cuboctahedral cages consisting of the linkage of [Mn4(COO)8] SBUs and BTTC3- ligands (g,h). The close packing of these octahedral and cuboctahedral cages is also similar to that of MOF-Mn  4  Cl, resulting in the 3D framework of MOF-Mn  4  with  the  topology (d,i,j). Interestingly, there is an isolated [Mn(OH)2(H2O)4] unit inside each twisted octahedral cage (g). The solvent accessible volume of MOF-Mn  4  is about 62.5% of the total crystal volume, which is slight lower than that of MOF-Mn  4  Cl. Thus, it can be considered as successful tuning of the coordination environment of SBUs in MOF-Mn  4  Cl. Meanwhile, the original anionic framework turns into a neutral one. In the previous work, Zhou's group presented a neutral meso-MOF-2, which was constructed by connecting square-planar tetranuclear Cd(II) SBUs with BTTC3- ligands, and retained permanent porosity upon heating activation. MOF-Mn  4  is isostructural with meso-MOF-2 because of the presence of a square-planar tetranuclear Mn(II) unit which has not been reported so far. It encourages us to explore the gas sorption property of MOF-Mn  4 .

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement confirmed the phase purity of MOF-Mn 4 Cl (a,b). To examine the stability of MOF-Mn 4 Cl, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and desolvation experiments were carried out. The TGA results show that MOF-Mn 4 Cl releases guest molecules between 25 and 250 °C, leading to a weight loss of 31% (Figure S1). To completely remove guest molecules in the voids by degassing, solvent exchange is performed by soaking crystals of MOF-Mn 4 Cl in CH2Cl2 under ambient conditions for 24 h, and then the CH2Cl2-exchanged sample is degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to form desolvated solid MOF-Mn 4 Cla. The PXRD pattern of desolvated solid MOF-Mn 4 Cla is distinct from that of the original MOF-Mn 4 Cl, confirming the host framework appears to undergo significant pore collapse upon guest removal (c). This phenomenon was often seen in some high porous MOFs. The TGA curve of MOF-Mn 4 shows that the guest molecules escape at a higher temperature (Figure S1). So, CH2Cl2-exchange is also performed for crystals of MOF-Mn 4 , which is further degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to give the desolvated solid MOF-Mn 4 a, whose PXRD pattern is matched well with that of original MOF-Mn 4 , confirming the integrity of the framework upon guest removal (c–e). In order to deeply understand the thermostability of host framework, MOF-Mn 4 is also degassed under 220, 250, and 280 °C, giving MOF-Mn 4 b, MOF-Mn 4 c, and MOF-Mn 4 d, respectively. PXRD pattern results indicate that the host framework of MOF-Mn 4 is stable under 250 °C and high vacuum. It is noted that high porous MOFs with such excellent thermostability are rarely reported. Once the activated temperature rises to 280 °C, the collapse of most host framework can be verified by PXRD patterns and gas sorption shown as below.
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement confirmed the phase purity of MOF-Mn  4  Cl (a,b). To examine the stability of MOF-Mn  4  Cl, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and desolvation experiments were carried out. The TGA results show that MOF-Mn  4  Cl releases guest molecules between 25 and 250 °C, leading to a weight loss of 31% (Figure S1). To completely remove guest molecules in the voids by degassing, solvent exchange is performed by soaking crystals of MOF-Mn  4  Cl in CH2Cl2 under ambient conditions for 24 h, and then the CH2Cl2-exchanged sample is degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to form desolvated solid MOF-Mn  4  Cla. The PXRD pattern of desolvated solid MOF-Mn  4  Cla is distinct from that of the original MOF-Mn  4  Cl, confirming the host framework appears to undergo significant pore collapse upon guest removal (c). This phenomenon was often seen in some high porous MOFs. The TGA curve of MOF-Mn  4  shows that the guest molecules escape at a higher temperature (Figure S1). So, CH2Cl2-exchange is also performed for crystals of MOF-Mn  4 , which is further degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to give the desolvated solid MOF-Mn  4  a, whose PXRD pattern is matched well with that of original MOF-Mn  4 , confirming the integrity of the framework upon guest removal (c-e). In order to deeply understand the thermostability of host framework, MOF-Mn  4  is also degassed under 220, 250, and 280 °C, giving MOF-Mn  4  b, MOF-Mn  4  c, and MOF-Mn  4  d, respectively. PXRD pattern results indicate that the host framework of MOF-Mn  4  is stable under 250 °C and high vacuum. It is noted that high porous MOFs with such excellent thermostability are rarely reported. Once the activated temperature rises to 280 °C, the collapse of most host framework can be verified by PXRD patterns and gas sorption shown as below.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of simulated one of MOF-Mn 4 Cl (a), as-synthesized MOF-Mn 4 Cl (b), MOF-Mn 4 Cla (c), simulated one of MOF-Mn 4 (d), as-synthesized MOF-Mn 4 (e), MOF-Mn 4 a (f), MOF-Mn 4 c (g), MOF-Mn 4 d (h).
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of simulated one of MOF-Mn  4  Cl (a), as-synthesized MOF-Mn  4  Cl (b), MOF-Mn  4  Cla (c), simulated one of MOF-Mn  4  (d), as-synthesized MOF-Mn  4  (e), MOF-Mn  4  a (f), MOF-Mn  4  c (g), MOF-Mn  4  d (h).

elements.content: Since both MOF-Mn 4 Cl and MOF-Mn 4 possess a similar porous structure and same topology, it provides a platform to comparatively study that how slight structural changes influence gas sorption performance. The N2 sorption isotherms reveals that MOF-Mn 4 Cla has a very low N2 uptake of 64.5 cm3/g at 77 K and 1 bar, giving low Langmuir and BET surface areas of 225 and 194 m2/g, respectively (a). The surface area and porosity parameters of the activated sample MOF-Mn 4 a–d are also analyzed by standard N2 analysis at 77 K. As shown in b–e, all of the samples display Type I isotherm with a steep nitrogen gas uptake at low relative pressure (P < 0.1 bar), indicating permanent microporosity of the framework. The BET surface area for MOF-Mn4a is calculated to be 1282 m2/g. In a series of the activated sample, MOF-Mn4c shows the highest gas uptake of 427.6 cm3/g and BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which are about an 8 times enhancement over those of the anionic MOF-Mn 4 Cl and comparable to MOFs that based on square-planar M4X (M = metal ions, X = Cl, O, or not exist) SBUs (Table S2). Being different from the isostructural meso-MOF-2, MOF-Mn 4 c shows a much higher N2 uptake than meso-MOF-2, and no terthienobenzene loss can be observed in MOF-Mn4c, further affirming its excellent thermostability. The experimental total pore volume of MOF-Mn4c is 0.66 cm3/g, which is slightly lower than that (0.76 cm3/g) estimated from the single crystal structure without all dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules. For MOF-Mn4a–c, the pore size distribution evaluated from a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) simulation of the N2 sorption curve indicates that the average pore size increases with the increasing of activated temperature (Figure S2). Under 77 K and 800 mmHg, the H2 capacity of MOF-Mn 4 a is 109 cm3/g (0.97 wt %), which can be compared with those of many reported MOFs. (Figure S3). The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for MOF-Mn 4 a is estimated from the H2 sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K by using the virial equation to understand the affinity of MOF-Mn 4 a toward H2, giving an isosteric heat of 5.3 kJ/mol (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: Since both MOF-Mn  4  Cl and MOF-Mn  4  possess a similar porous structure and same topology, it provides a platform to comparatively study that how slight structural changes influence gas sorption performance. The N2 sorption isotherms reveals that MOF-Mn  4  Cla has a very low N2 uptake of 64.5 cm3/g at 77 K and 1 bar, giving low Langmuir and BET surface areas of 225 and 194 m2/g, respectively (a). The surface area and porosity parameters of the activated sample MOF-Mn  4  a-d are also analyzed by standard N2 analysis at 77 K. As shown in b-e, all of the samples display Type I isotherm with a steep nitrogen gas uptake at low relative pressure (P < 0.1 bar), indicating permanent microporosity of the framework. The BET surface area for MOF-Mn4a is calculated to be 1282 m2/g. In a series of the activated sample, MOF-Mn4c shows the highest gas uptake of 427.6 cm3/g and BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which are about an 8 times enhancement over those of the anionic MOF-Mn  4  Cl and comparable to MOFs that based on square-planar M4X (M = metal ions, X = Cl, O, or not exist) SBUs (Table S2). Being different from the isostructural meso-MOF-2, MOF-Mn  4  c shows a much higher N2 uptake than meso-MOF-2, and no terthienobenzene loss can be observed in MOF-Mn4c, further affirming its excellent thermostability. The experimental total pore volume of MOF-Mn4c is 0.66 cm3/g, which is slightly lower than that (0.76 cm3/g) estimated from the single crystal structure without all dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules. For MOF-Mn4a-c, the pore size distribution evaluated from a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) simulation of the N2 sorption curve indicates that the average pore size increases with the increasing of activated temperature (Figure S2). Under 77 K and 800 mmHg, the H2 capacity of MOF-Mn  4  a is 109 cm3/g (0.97 wt %), which can be compared with those of many reported MOFs. (Figure S3). The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for MOF-Mn  4  a is estimated from the H2 sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K by using the virial equation to understand the affinity of MOF-Mn  4  a toward H2, giving an isosteric heat of 5.3 kJ/mol (Figure S4).

elements.content: N2 Gas sorption isotherms at 77 K: (a) MOF-Mn 4 Cla; (b) MOF-Mn 4 a; (c) MOF-Mn 4 b; (d) MOF-Mn 4 c; (e) MOF-Mn 4 d.
elements.clean_text: 3  N2 Gas sorption isotherms at 77 K: (a) MOF-Mn  4  Cla; (b) MOF-Mn  4  a; (c) MOF-Mn  4  b; (d) MOF-Mn  4  c; (e) MOF-Mn  4  d.

elements.content: The different adsorption properties of MOF-Mn 4 and MOF-Mn 4 Cl are mainly caused by the change of coordination environment in SBUs. MOF-Mn 4 and MOF-Mn 4 Cl have a similar porous structure and the same topology, but the Mn–Cl bond with a long bond length in MOF-Mn 4 Cl is apt to break during solvent-exchange and degassing processes, causing significant pore collapse in the host framework. While each Mn–Cl bond is substituted by two weak coordination interactions of Mn1···O3 in MOF-Mn 4 , the multiplicate metal–ligand affinity contributes to maintain the integrity of the framework upon guest removal. However, such weak interactions cannot be observed in MOF-Mn 4 Cl because of the long distance of 3.635 Å between Mn and O atoms.
elements.clean_text: The different adsorption properties of MOF-Mn  4  and MOF-Mn  4  Cl are mainly caused by the change of coordination environment in SBUs. MOF-Mn  4  and MOF-Mn  4  Cl have a similar porous structure and the same topology, but the Mn-Cl bond with a long bond length in MOF-Mn  4  Cl is apt to break during solvent-exchange and degassing processes, causing significant pore collapse in the host framework. While each Mn-Cl bond is substituted by two weak coordination interactions of Mn1⋅⋅⋅O3 in MOF-Mn  4 , the multiplicate metal-ligand affinity contributes to maintain the integrity of the framework upon guest removal. However, such weak interactions cannot be observed in MOF-Mn  4  Cl because of the long distance of 3.635 Å between Mn and O atoms.

elements.content: In conclusion, by varying the coordination environment in SBUs, two Mn­(II)-BTTC frameworks with the topology are successfully synthesized, which are constructed by the close packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages. It is interesting that the slight change of coordination environment in SBUs makes a huge difference in framework stability and gas sorption property between the two Mn­(II)-BTTC MOFs. The results reveal that the multiplicate metal–ligand interactions would be benefit for enhancing the MOFs’ stability.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, by varying the coordination environment in SBUs, two Mn(II)-BTTC frameworks with  the  topology are successfully synthesized, which are constructed by the close packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages. It is interesting that the slight change of coordination environment in SBUs makes a huge difference in framework stability and gas sorption property between the two Mn(II)-BTTC MOFs. The results reveal that the multiplicate metal-ligand interactions would be benefit for enhancing the MOFs' stability.

cln_elements.content:
By regulating secondary building units and inducing multiplicate metal–ligand interactions, an unstable anionic framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust neutral framework MOF-Mn4 . Although possessing same network topology, MOF-Mn4 shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over MOF-Mn4Cl.

On the basis of the idea of regulating the coordination environment of secondary building units in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) via inducing multiplicate metal−ligand interactions, an unstable framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust framework MOF-Mn4 . Although both MOFs possess similar the -type topologies and pore features, the neutral stable MOF-Mn4 shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over the unstable anionic MOF-Mn4Cl.

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement confirmed the phase purity of MOF-Mn 4 Cl (a,b). To examine the stability of MOF-Mn 4 Cl, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and desolvation experiments were carried out. The TGA results show that MOF-Mn 4 Cl releases guest molecules between 25 and 250 °C, leading to a weight loss of 31% (Figure S1). To completely remove guest molecules in the voids by degassing, solvent exchange is performed by soaking crystals of MOF-Mn 4 Cl in CH2Cl2 under ambient conditions for 24 h, and then the CH2Cl2-exchanged sample is degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to form desolvated solid MOF-Mn 4 Cla. The PXRD pattern of desolvated solid MOF-Mn 4 Cla is distinct from that of the original MOF-Mn 4 Cl, confirming the host framework appears to undergo significant pore collapse upon guest removal (c). This phenomenon was often seen in some high porous MOFs. The TGA curve of MOF-Mn 4 shows that the guest molecules escape at a higher temperature (Figure S1). So, CH2Cl2-exchange is also performed for crystals of MOF-Mn 4 , which is further degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to give the desolvated solid MOF-Mn 4 a, whose PXRD pattern is matched well with that of original MOF-Mn 4 , confirming the integrity of the framework upon guest removal (c–e). In order to deeply understand the thermostability of host framework, MOF-Mn 4 is also degassed under 220, 250, and 280 °C, giving MOF-Mn 4 b, MOF-Mn 4 c, and MOF-Mn 4 d, respectively. PXRD pattern results indicate that the host framework of MOF-Mn 4 is stable under 250 °C and high vacuum. It is noted that high porous MOFs with such excellent thermostability are rarely reported. Once the activated temperature rises to 280 °C, the collapse of most host framework can be verified by PXRD patterns and gas sorption shown as below.

Since both MOF-Mn 4 Cl and MOF-Mn 4 possess a similar porous structure and same topology, it provides a platform to comparatively study that how slight structural changes influence gas sorption performance. The N2 sorption isotherms reveals that MOF-Mn 4 Cla has a very low N2 uptake of 64.5 cm3/g at 77 K and 1 bar, giving low Langmuir and BET surface areas of 225 and 194 m2/g, respectively (a). The surface area and porosity parameters of the activated sample MOF-Mn 4 a–d are also analyzed by standard N2 analysis at 77 K. As shown in b–e, all of the samples display Type I isotherm with a steep nitrogen gas uptake at low relative pressure (P < 0.1 bar), indicating permanent microporosity of the framework. The BET surface area for MOF-Mn4a is calculated to be 1282 m2/g. In a series of the activated sample, MOF-Mn4c shows the highest gas uptake of 427.6 cm3/g and BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which are about an 8 times enhancement over those of the anionic MOF-Mn 4 Cl and comparable to MOFs that based on square-planar M4X (M = metal ions, X = Cl, O, or not exist) SBUs (Table S2). Being different from the isostructural meso-MOF-2, MOF-Mn 4 c shows a much higher N2 uptake than meso-MOF-2, and no terthienobenzene loss can be observed in MOF-Mn4c, further affirming its excellent thermostability. The experimental total pore volume of MOF-Mn4c is 0.66 cm3/g, which is slightly lower than that (0.76 cm3/g) estimated from the single crystal structure without all dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules. For MOF-Mn4a–c, the pore size distribution evaluated from a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) simulation of the N2 sorption curve indicates that the average pore size increases with the increasing of activated temperature (Figure S2). Under 77 K and 800 mmHg, the H2 capacity of MOF-Mn 4 a is 109 cm3/g (0.97 wt %), which can be compared with those of many reported MOFs. (Figure S3). The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for MOF-Mn 4 a is estimated from the H2 sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K by using the virial equation to understand the affinity of MOF-Mn 4 a toward H2, giving an isosteric heat of 5.3 kJ/mol (Figure S4).

Although possessing same network topology, MOF-Mn4  shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over MOF-Mn4Cl.

On the basis of the idea of regulating the coordination environment of secondary building units in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) via inducing multiplicate metal-ligand interactions, an unstable framework MOF-Mn4Cl is structurally modified into a robust framework MOF-Mn4 . Although both MOFs possess similar  the -type topologies and pore features, the neutral stable MOF-Mn4  shows a high BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which is about an 8 times enhancement over the unstable anionic MOF-Mn4Cl.

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement confirmed the phase purity of MOF-Mn  4  Cl (a,b). To examine the stability of MOF-Mn  4  Cl, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and desolvation experiments were carried out. The TGA results show that MOF-Mn  4  Cl releases guest molecules between 25 and 250 °C, leading to a weight loss of 31% (Figure S1). So, CH2Cl2-exchange is also performed for crystals of MOF-Mn  4 , which is further degassed under high vacuum (5 μmHg) at room temperature overnight to give the desolvated solid MOF-Mn  4  a, whose PXRD pattern is matched well with that of original MOF-Mn  4 , confirming the integrity of the framework upon guest removal (c-e). In order to deeply understand the thermostability of host framework, MOF-Mn  4  is also degassed under 220, 250, and 280 °C, giving MOF-Mn  4  b, MOF-Mn  4  c, and MOF-Mn  4  d, respectively. Once the activated temperature rises to 280 °C, the collapse of most host framework can be verified by PXRD patterns and gas sorption shown as below.

Since both MOF-Mn  4  Cl and MOF-Mn  4  possess a similar porous structure and same topology, it provides a platform to comparatively study that how slight structural changes influence gas sorption performance. The N2 sorption isotherms reveals that MOF-Mn  4  Cla has a very low N2 uptake of 64.5 cm3/g at 77 K and 1 bar, giving low Langmuir and BET surface areas of 225 and 194 m2/g, respectively (a). In a series of the activated sample, MOF-Mn4c shows the highest gas uptake of 427.6 cm3/g and BET surface area of 1718 m2/g, which are about an 8 times enhancement over those of the anionic MOF-Mn  4  Cl and comparable to MOFs that based on square-planar M4X (M = metal ions, X = Cl, O, or not exist) SBUs (Table S2). Being different from the isostructural meso-MOF-2, MOF-Mn  4  c shows a much higher N2 uptake than meso-MOF-2, and no terthienobenzene loss can be observed in MOF-Mn4c, further affirming its excellent thermostability. The experimental total pore volume of MOF-Mn4c is 0.66 cm3/g, which is slightly lower than that (0.76 cm3/g) estimated from the single crystal structure without all dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules. For MOF-Mn4a-c, the pore size distribution evaluated from a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) simulation of the N2 sorption curve indicates that the average pore size increases with the increasing of activated temperature (Figure S2). Under 77 K and 800 mmHg, the H2 capacity of MOF-Mn  4  a is 109 cm3/g (0.97 wt %), which can be compared with those of many reported MOFs. (Figure S3). The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for MOF-Mn  4  a is estimated from the H2 sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K by using the virial equation to understand the affinity of MOF-Mn  4  a toward H2, giving an isosteric heat of 5.3 kJ/mol (Figure S4).

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

porosity.condition: experimental total pore volume for MOF-Mn4c

cln_elements.content: Crystal structures of MOF-Mn 4 Cl and MOF-Mn 4 . (a) The coordination environment of [Mn4(μ4-Cl)­(COO)8]− SBU and BTTC ligand in MOF-Mn 4 Cl (gray: C; red: O; yellow: S; violet: Mn; lime: Cl). (b) The truncated octahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 Cl. (c) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 Cl. (d) The cubic packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages via sharing all of the triangular facets in both MOFs. (e) The diagram of the 3D framework of MOF-Mn 4 Cl. (f) The coordination environment of [Mn4(COO)8]− SBU and BTTC ligand in MOF-Mn 4 . (g) The truncated octahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 , in which [Mn­(OH)2­(H2O)4] unit is wrapped. (h) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn 4 . (i) 3,8-Connected the topology derived from the structure of both MOFs. (j) The diagram of the 3D framework of MOF-Mn 4 .

(c) The cuboctahedral cage in MOF-Mn  4  Cl. (d) The cubic packing of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages via sharing all of the triangular facets in both MOFs. metadata.title:
Comparative Stability and Sorption Study of Two 
the
-type Metal–Organic Frameworks with
Different Multiplicate Metal–Ligand Interactions in Secondary
Building Units
